description: A compressor is mainly used to reduce the dynamic range of a signal. Especially modern music is mostly compressed at a high ratio to improve the overall loudness. It’s done to get the highest attention of a listener, "fatten" the sound and bring more "power" to the track. If a signal is compressed too much it may sound dull or "dead" afterwards or it may start to "pump" (which could be a powerful effect but can also destroy a track completely). The right compression is the key to reach a professional sound and is the high art of mixing and mastering. Because of its complex settings it may take a long time to get the right feeling for this kind of effect.
Compression is done by detecting the volume above a chosen level

threshold and dividing it by the factor set with ratio. So if you set the threshold to -12dB and your signal reaches -6dB a ratio of 2:1 will result in a signal at -9dB. Because an exact manipulation of the signal would cause distortion of the waveform the reduction can be levelled over the time. This is done by setting "Attack" and "Release".

attack determines how long the signal has to rise above the threshold before any reduction will occur and release sets the time the signal has to fall below the threshold to reduce the reduction again. Shorter signals than the chosen attack time will be left untouched. The overall reduction of the signal can be made up afterwards with the

makeup setting. So compressing the peaks of a signal about 6dB and raising the makeup to this level results in a signal twice as loud than the source. To gain a softer entry in the compression the knee flattens the hard edge at the threshold in the range of the chosen decibels.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: acompressor

parameters.name: level_in
description: Set input gain. Default is 1. Range is between 0.015625 and 64.

parameters.name: mode
description: Set mode of compressor operation. Can be upward or downward. Default is downward.

parameters.name: threshold
description: If a signal of stream rises above this level it will affect the gain reduction. By default it is 0.125. Range is between 0.00097563 and 1.

parameters.name: ratio
description: Set a ratio by which the signal is reduced. 1:2 means that if the level rose 4dB above the threshold, it will be only 2dB above after the reduction. Default is 2. Range is between 1 and 20.

parameters.name: attack
description: Amount of milliseconds the signal has to rise above the threshold before gain reduction starts. Default is 20. Range is between 0.01 and 2000.

parameters.name: release
description: Amount of milliseconds the signal has to fall below the threshold before reduction is decreased again. Default is 250. Range is between 0.01 and 9000.

parameters.name: makeup
description: Set the amount by how much signal will be amplified after processing. Default is 1. Range is from 1 to 64.

parameters.name: knee
description: Curve the sharp knee around the threshold to enter gain reduction more softly. Default is 2.82843. Range is between 1 and 8.

parameters.name: link
description: Choose if the average level between all channels of input stream or the louder(maximum) channel of input stream affects the reduction. Default is average.

parameters.name: detection
description: Should the exact signal be taken in case of peak or an RMS one in case of rms. Default is rms which is mostly smoother.

parameters.name: mix
description: How much to use compressed signal in output. Default is 1. Range is between 0 and 1.
Simple audio dynamic range compression/expansion filter.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: acontrast

parameters.name: contrast
description: Set contrast. Default is 33. Allowed range is between 0 and 100.
Copy the input audio source unchanged to the output. This is mainly useful for testing purposes.
name: acopy

description: Apply cross fade from one input audio stream to another input audio stream. The cross fade is applied for specified duration near the end of first stream.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: acrossfade

parameters.name: nb_samples
description: Specify the number of samples for which the cross fade effect has to last. At the end of the cross fade effect the first input audio will be completely silent. Default is 44100.

parameters.name: duration
description: Specify the duration of the cross fade effect. See
(ffmpeg-utils)the Time duration section in the ffmpeg-utils(1) manual for the accepted syntax. By default the duration is determined by nb_samples. If set this option is used instead of nb_samples.

parameters.name: overlap
description: Should first stream end overlap with second stream start. Default is enabled.

parameters.name: curve1
description: Set curve for cross fade transition for first stream.

parameters.name: curve2
description: Set curve for cross fade transition for second stream.
For description of available curve types see afade filter description.
Split audio stream into several bands.
This filter splits audio stream into two or more frequency ranges. Summing all streams back will give flat output.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: acrossover

parameters.name: split
description: Set split frequencies. Those must be positive and increasing.

parameters.name: order
description: Set filter order, can be 2nd, 4th or 8th. Default is 4th.
Reduce audio bit resolution.

This filter is bit crusher with enhanced functionality. A bit crusher is used to audibly reduce number of bits an audio signal is sampled with. This doesn’t change the bit depth at all, it just produces the effect. Material reduced in bit depth sounds more harsh and "digital". This filter is able to even round to continuous values instead of discrete bit depths. Additionally it has a D/C offset which results in different crushing of the lower and the upper half of the signal. An Anti-Aliasing setting is able to produce "softer" crushing sounds.

Another feature of this filter is the logarithmic mode. This setting switches from linear distances between bits to logarithmic ones. The result is a much more "natural" sounding crusher which doesn’t gate low signals for example. The human ear has a logarithmic perception, so this kind of crushing is much more pleasant. Logarithmic crushing is also able to get anti-aliased.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: acrusher

parameters.name: level_in
description: Set level in.

parameters.name: level_out
description: Set level out.

parameters.name: bits
description: Set bit reduction.

parameters.name: mix
description: Set mixing amount.

parameters.name: mode
description: Can be linear: lin or logarithmic: log.

parameters.name: dc
description: Set DC.

parameters.name: aa
description: Set anti-aliasing.

parameters.name: samples
description: Set sample reduction.

parameters.name: lfo
description: Enable LFO. By default disabled.

parameters.name: lforange
description: Set LFO range.

parameters.name: lforate
description: Set LFO rate.
Delay audio filtering until a given wallclock timestamp. See the cue filter.
name: acue

description: Remove impulsive noise from input audio.
Samples detected as impulsive noise are replaced by interpolated samples using autoregressive modelling.
name: adeclick

parameters.name: w
description: Set window size, in milliseconds. Allowed range is from 10 to
100. Default value is 55 milliseconds. This sets size of window which will be processed at once.

parameters.name: o
description: Set window overlap, in percentage of window size. Allowed range is from
50 to 95. Default value is 75 percent. Setting this to a very high value increases impulsive noise removal but makes whole process much slower.

parameters.name: a
description: Set autoregression order, in percentage of window size. Allowed range is from
0 to 25. Default value is 2 percent. This option also controls quality of interpolated samples using neighbour good samples.

parameters.name: t
description: Set threshold value. Allowed range is from 1 to 100. Default value is 2. This controls the strength of impulsive noise which is going to be removed. The lower value, the more samples will be detected as impulsive noise.

parameters.name: b
description: Set burst fusion, in percentage of window size. Allowed range is 0 to
10. Default value is 2. If any two samples detected as noise are spaced less than this value then any sample between those two samples will be also detected as noise.

parameters.name: m
description: Set overlap method.
It accepts the following values:
a
Select overlap-add method. Even not interpolated samples are slightly changed with this method.
s
Select overlap-save method. Not interpolated samples remain unchanged.
Default value is a.
Remove clipped samples from input audio.
Samples detected as clipped are replaced by interpolated samples using autoregressive modelling.
name: adeclip

parameters.name: w
description: Set window size, in milliseconds. Allowed range is from 10 to 100. Default value is 55 milliseconds. This sets size of window which will be processed at once.

parameters.name: o
description: Set window overlap, in percentage of window size. Allowed range is from 50 to 95. Default value is 75 percent.

parameters.name: a
description: Set autoregression order, in percentage of window size. Allowed range is from
0 to 25. Default value is 8 percent. This option also controls quality of interpolated samples using neighbour good samples.

parameters.name: t
description: Set threshold value. Allowed range is from 1 to 100. Default value is 10. Higher values make clip detection less aggressive.

parameters.name: n
description: Set size of histogram used to detect clips. Allowed range is from 100 to 9999. Default value is 1000. Higher values make clip detection less aggressive.

parameters.name: m
description: Set overlap method.
It accepts the following values:
a
Select overlap-add method. Even not interpolated samples are slightly changed with this method.
s
Select overlap-save method. Not interpolated samples remain unchanged.
Default value is a.
Delay one or more audio channels.
Samples in delayed channel are filled with silence.
The filter accepts the following option:
name: adelay

parameters.name: delays
description: Set list of delays in milliseconds for each channel separated by ’|’. Unused delays will be silently ignored. If number of given delays is smaller than number of channels all remaining channels will not be delayed. If you want to delay exact number of samples, append ’S’ to number. If you want instead to delay in seconds, append ’s’ to number.

parameters.name: all
description: Use last set delay for all remaining channels. By default is disabled. This option if enabled changes how option delays is interpreted.
Compute derivative/integral of audio stream.
Applying both filters one after another produces original audio.
name: aderivative

description: Compute derivative/integral of audio stream.
Applying both filters one after another produces original audio.
name: aintegral

description: Apply echoing to the input audio.

Echoes are reflected sound and can occur naturally amongst mountains (and sometimes large buildings) when talking or shouting; digital echo effects emulate this behaviour and are often used to help fill out the sound of a single instrument or vocal. The time difference between the original signal and the reflection is the delay, and the loudness of the reflected signal is the decay. Multiple echoes can have different delays and decays.
A description of the accepted parameters follows.
name: aecho

parameters.name: in_gain
description: Set input gain of reflected signal. Default is 0.6.

parameters.name: out_gain
description: Set output gain of reflected signal. Default is 0.3.

parameters.name: delays
description: Set list of time intervals in milliseconds between original signal and reflections separated by ’|’. Allowed range for each delay is (0 - 90000.0]. Default is 1000.

parameters.name: decays
description: Set list of loudness of reflected signals separated by ’|’. Allowed range for each decay is (0 - 1.0]. Default is 0.5.

Audio emphasis filter creates or restores material directly taken from LPs or emphased CDs with different filter curves. E.g. to store music on vinyl the signal has to be altered by a filter first to even out the disadvantages of this recording medium. Once the material is played back the inverse filter has to be applied to restore the distortion of the frequency response.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: aemphasis

parameters.name: level_in
description: Set input gain.

parameters.name: level_out
description: Set output gain.

parameters.name: mode
description: Set filter mode. For restoring material use reproduction mode, otherwise use production mode. Default is reproduction mode.

parameters.name: type
description: Set filter type. Selects medium. Can be one of the following:
col
select Columbia.
emi
select EMI.
bsi
select BSI (78RPM).
riaa
select RIAA.
cd
select Compact Disc (CD).
50fm
select 50µs (FM).
75fm
select 75µs (FM).
50kf
select 50µs (FM-KF).
75kf
select 75µs (FM-KF).
Modify an audio signal according to the specified expressions.
This filter accepts one or more expressions (one for each channel), which are evaluated and used to modify a corresponding audio signal.
It accepts the following parameters:
name: aeval

parameters.name: exprs
description: Set the ’|’-separated expressions list for each separate channel. If the number of input channels is greater than the number of expressions, the last specified expression is used for the remaining output channels.

parameters.name: channel_layout
description: Set output channel layout. If not specified, the channel layout is specified by the number of expressions. If set to ‘same’, it will use by default the same input channel layout.
Apply fade-in/out effect to input audio.
A description of the accepted parameters follows.
name: afade

parameters.name: type
description: Specify the effect type, can be either in for fade-in, or
out for a fade-out effect. Default is in.

parameters.name: start_sample
description: Specify the number of the start sample for starting to apply the fade effect. Default is 0.

parameters.name: nb_samples
description: Specify the number of samples for which the fade effect has to last. At the end of the fade-in effect the output audio will have the same volume as the input audio, at the end of the fade-out transition the output audio will be silence. Default is 44100.

parameters.name: start_time
description: Specify the start time of the fade effect. Default is 0. The value must be specified as a time duration; see
(ffmpeg-utils)the Time duration section in the ffmpeg-utils(1) manual for the accepted syntax. If set this option is used instead of start_sample.

parameters.name: duration
description: Specify the duration of the fade effect. See

(ffmpeg-utils)the Time duration section in the ffmpeg-utils(1) manual for the accepted syntax. At the end of the fade-in effect the output audio will have the same volume as the input audio, at the end of the fade-out transition the output audio will be silence. By default the duration is determined by nb_samples. If set this option is used instead of nb_samples.

parameters.name: curve
description: Set curve for fade transition.
It accepts the following values:
tri
select triangular, linear slope (default)
qsin
select quarter of sine wave
hsin
select half of sine wave
esin
select exponential sine wave
log
select logarithmic
ipar
select inverted parabola
qua
select quadratic
cub
select cubic
squ
select square root
cbr
select cubic root
par
select parabola
exp
select exponential
iqsin
select inverted quarter of sine wave
ihsin
select inverted half of sine wave
dese
select double-exponential seat
desi
select double-exponential sigmoid
losi
select logistic sigmoid
nofade
no fade applied
Denoise audio samples with FFT.
A description of the accepted parameters follows.
name: afftdn

parameters.name: nr
description: Set the noise reduction in dB, allowed range is 0.01 to 97. Default value is 12 dB.

parameters.name: nf
description: Set the noise floor in dB, allowed range is -80 to -20. Default value is -50 dB.

parameters.name: nt
description: Set the noise type.
It accepts the following values:
w
Select white noise.
v
Select vinyl noise.
s
Select shellac noise.
c
Select custom noise, defined in bn option.
Default value is white noise.

parameters.name: bn
description: Set custom band noise for every one of 15 bands. Bands are separated by ’ ’ or ’|’.

parameters.name: rf
description: Set the residual floor in dB, allowed range is -80 to -20. Default value is -38 dB.

parameters.name: tn
description: Enable noise tracking. By default is disabled. With this enabled, noise floor is automatically adjusted.

parameters.name: tr
description: Enable residual tracking. By default is disabled.

parameters.name: om
description: Set the output mode.
It accepts the following values:
i
Pass input unchanged.
o
Pass noise filtered out.
n
Pass only noise.
Default value is o.
Apply arbitrary expressions to samples in frequency domain.
name: afftfilt

parameters.name: real
description: Set frequency domain real expression for each separate channel separated by ’|’. Default is "re". If the number of input channels is greater than the number of expressions, the last specified expression is used for the remaining output channels.

parameters.name: imag
description: Set frequency domain imaginary expression for each separate channel separated by ’|’. Default is "im".
Each expression in real and imag can contain the following constants and functions:
sr
sample rate
b
current frequency bin number
nb
number of available bins
ch
channel number of the current expression
chs
number of channels
pts
current frame pts
re
current real part of frequency bin of current channel
im
current imaginary part of frequency bin of current channel
real(b, ch)
Return the value of real part of frequency bin at location (bin,channel)
imag(b, ch)
Return the value of imaginary part of frequency bin at location (bin,channel)

parameters.name: win_size
description: Set window size. Allowed range is from 16 to 131072. Default is 4096

parameters.name: win_func
description: Set window function. Default is hann.

parameters.name: overlap
description: Set window overlap. If set to 1, the recommended overlap for selected window function will be picked. Default is 0.75.
Apply an arbitrary Finite Impulse Response filter.
This filter is designed for applying long FIR filters, up to 60 seconds long.
It can be used as component for digital crossover filters, room equalization, cross talk cancellation, wavefield synthesis, auralization, ambiophonics, ambisonics and spatialization.

This filter uses the streams higher than first one as FIR coefficients. If the non-first stream holds a single channel, it will be used for all input channels in the first stream, otherwise the number of channels in the non-first stream must be same as the number of channels in the first stream.
It accepts the following parameters:
name: afir

parameters.name: dry
description: Set dry gain. This sets input gain.

parameters.name: wet
description: Set wet gain. This sets final output gain.

parameters.name: length
description: Set Impulse Response filter length. Default is 1, which means whole IR is processed.

parameters.name: gtype
description: Enable applying gain measured from power of IR.
Set which approach to use for auto gain measurement.
none
Do not apply any gain.
peak
select peak gain, very conservative approach. This is default value.
dc
select DC gain, limited application.
gn
select gain to noise approach, this is most popular one.

parameters.name: irgain
description: Set gain to be applied to IR coefficients before filtering. Allowed range is 0 to 1. This gain is applied after any gain applied with gtype option.

parameters.name: irfmt
description: Set format of IR stream. Can be mono or input. Default is input.

parameters.name: maxir
description: Set max allowed Impulse Response filter duration in seconds. Default is 30 seconds. Allowed range is 0.1 to 60 seconds.

parameters.name: response
description: Show IR frequency response, magnitude(magenta), phase(green) and group delay(yellow) in additional video stream. By default it is disabled.

parameters.name: channel
description: Set for which IR channel to display frequency response. By default is first channel displayed. This option is used only when response is enabled.

parameters.name: size
description: Set video stream size. This option is used only when response is enabled.

parameters.name: rate
description: Set video stream frame rate. This option is used only when response is enabled.

parameters.name: minp
description: Set minimal partition size used for convolution. Default is 8192. Allowed range is from 1 to 32768. Lower values decreases latency at cost of higher CPU usage.

parameters.name: maxp
description: Set maximal partition size used for convolution. Default is 8192. Allowed range is from 8 to 32768. Lower values may increase CPU usage.

parameters.name: nbirs
description: Set number of input impulse responses streams which will be switchable at runtime. Allowed range is from 1 to 32. Default is 1.

parameters.name: ir
description: Set IR stream which will be used for convolution, starting from 0, should always be lower than supplied value by nbirs option. Default is 0. This option can be changed at runtime via commands.
Set output format constraints for the input audio. The framework will negotiate the most appropriate format to minimize conversions.
It accepts the following parameters:
name: aformat

parameters.name: sample_fmts
description: A ’|’-separated list of requested sample formats.

parameters.name: sample_rates
description: A ’|’-separated list of requested sample rates.

parameters.name: channel_layouts
description: A ’|’-separated list of requested channel layouts.
See (ffmpeg-utils)the Channel Layout section in the ffmpeg-utils(1) manual for the required syntax.
A gate is mainly used to reduce lower parts of a signal. This kind of signal processing reduces disturbing noise between useful signals.

Gating is done by detecting the volume below a chosen level threshold and dividing it by the factor set with ratio. The bottom of the noise floor is set via range. Because an exact manipulation of the signal would cause distortion of the waveform the reduction can be levelled over time. This is done by setting attack and release.

attack determines how long the signal has to fall below the threshold before any reduction will occur and release sets the time the signal has to rise above the threshold to reduce the reduction again. Shorter signals than the chosen attack time will be left untouched.
name: agate

parameters.name: level_in
description: Set input level before filtering. Default is 1. Allowed range is from 0.015625 to 64.

parameters.name: mode
description: Set the mode of operation. Can be upward or downward. Default is downward. If set to upward mode, higher parts of signal will be amplified, expanding dynamic range in upward direction. Otherwise, in case of downward lower parts of signal will be reduced.

parameters.name: range
description: Set the level of gain reduction when the signal is below the threshold. Default is 0.06125. Allowed range is from 0 to 1. Setting this to 0 disables reduction and then filter behaves like expander.

parameters.name: threshold
description: If a signal rises above this level the gain reduction is released. Default is 0.125. Allowed range is from 0 to 1.

parameters.name: ratio
description: Set a ratio by which the signal is reduced. Default is 2. Allowed range is from 1 to 9000.

parameters.name: attack
description: Amount of milliseconds the signal has to rise above the threshold before gain reduction stops. Default is 20 milliseconds. Allowed range is from 0.01 to 9000.

parameters.name: release
description: Amount of milliseconds the signal has to fall below the threshold before the reduction is increased again. Default is 250 milliseconds. Allowed range is from 0.01 to 9000.

parameters.name: makeup
description: Set amount of amplification of signal after processing. Default is 1. Allowed range is from 1 to 64.

parameters.name: knee
description: Curve the sharp knee around the threshold to enter gain reduction more softly. Default is 2.828427125. Allowed range is from 1 to 8.

parameters.name: detection
description: Choose if exact signal should be taken for detection or an RMS like one. Default is rms. Can be peak or rms.

parameters.name: link
description: Choose if the average level between all channels or the louder channel affects the reduction. Default is average. Can be average or maximum.
Apply an arbitrary Infinite Impulse Response filter.
It accepts the following parameters:
name: aiir

parameters.name: z
description: Set numerator/zeros coefficients.

parameters.name: p
description: Set denominator/poles coefficients.

parameters.name: k
description: Set channels gains.

parameters.name: dry_gain
description: Set input gain.

parameters.name: wet_gain
description: Set output gain.

parameters.name: f
description: Set coefficients format.
‘tf’
transfer function
‘zp’
Z-plane zeros/poles, cartesian (default)
‘pr’
Z-plane zeros/poles, polar radians
‘pd’
Z-plane zeros/poles, polar degrees

parameters.name: r
description: Set kind of processing. Can be d - direct or s - serial cascading. Default is s.

parameters.name: e
description: Set filtering precision.
‘dbl’
double-precision floating-point (default)
‘flt’
single-precision floating-point
32-bit integers
16-bit integers

parameters.name: mix
description: How much to use filtered signal in output. Default is 1. Range is between 0 and 1.

parameters.name: response
description: Show IR frequency response, magnitude(magenta), phase(green) and group delay(yellow) in additional video stream. By default it is disabled.

parameters.name: channel
description: Set for which IR channel to display frequency response. By default is first channel displayed. This option is used only when response is enabled.

parameters.name: size
description: Set video stream size. This option is used only when response is enabled.

The limiter prevents an input signal from rising over a desired threshold. This limiter uses lookahead technology to prevent your signal from distorting. It means that there is a small delay after the signal is processed. Keep in mind that the delay it produces is the attack time you set.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: alimiter

parameters.name: level_in
description: Set input gain. Default is 1.

parameters.name: level_out
description: Set output gain. Default is 1.

parameters.name: limit
description: Don’t let signals above this level pass the limiter. Default is 1.

parameters.name: attack
description: The limiter will reach its attenuation level in this amount of time in milliseconds. Default is 5 milliseconds.

parameters.name: release
description: Come back from limiting to attenuation 1.0 in this amount of milliseconds. Default is 50 milliseconds.

parameters.name: asc
description: When gain reduction is always needed ASC takes care of releasing to an average reduction level rather than reaching a reduction of 0 in the release time.

parameters.name: asc_level
description: Select how much the release time is affected by ASC, 0 means nearly no changes in release time while 1 produces higher release times.

parameters.name: level
description: Auto level output signal. Default is enabled. This normalizes audio back to 0dB if enabled.
Apply a two-pole all-pass filter with central frequency (in Hz)
frequency, and filter-width width. An all-pass filter changes the audio’s frequency to phase relationship without changing its frequency to amplitude relationship.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: allpass

parameters.name: frequency
description: Set frequency in Hz.

parameters.name: width_type
description: Set method to specify band-width of filter.
h
Hz
q
Q-Factor
o
octave
s
slope
k
kHz

parameters.name: width
description: Specify the band-width of a filter in width_type units.

parameters.name: mix
description: How much to use filtered signal in output. Default is 1. Range is between 0 and 1.

parameters.name: channels
description: Specify which channels to filter, by default all available are filtered.

parameters.name: normalize
description: Normalize biquad coefficients, by default is disabled. Enabling it will normalize magnitude response at DC to 0dB.
Loop audio samples.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: aloop

parameters.name: loop
description: Set the number of loops. Setting this value to -1 will result in infinite loops. Default is 0.

parameters.name: size
description: Set maximal number of samples. Default is 0.

parameters.name: start
description: Set first sample of loop. Default is 0.
Merge two or more audio streams into a single multi-channel stream.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: amerge

parameters.name: inputs
description: Set the number of inputs. Default is 2.
Mixes multiple audio inputs into a single output.

Note that this filter only supports float samples (the amerge and pan audio filters support many formats). If the amix input has integer samples then aresample will be automatically inserted to perform the conversion to float samples.
For example
ffmpeg -i INPUT1 -i INPUT2 -i INPUT3 -filter_complex amix=inputs=3:duration=first:dropout_transition=3 OUTPUT
will mix 3 input audio streams to a single output with the same duration as the first input and a dropout transition time of 3 seconds.
It accepts the following parameters:
name: amix

parameters.name: inputs
description: The number of inputs. If unspecified, it defaults to 2.

parameters.name: duration
description: How to determine the end-of-stream.
longest
The duration of the longest input. (default)
shortest
The duration of the shortest input.
first
The duration of the first input.

parameters.name: dropout_transition
description: The transition time, in seconds, for volume renormalization when an input stream ends. The default value is 2 seconds.

parameters.name: weights
description: Specify weight of each input audio stream as sequence. Each weight is separated by space. By default all inputs have same weight.

Multiply first audio stream with second audio stream and store result in output audio stream. Multiplication is done by multiplying each sample from first stream with sample at same position from second stream.
With this element-wise multiplication one can create amplitude fades and amplitude modulations.
name: amultiply

description: High-order parametric multiband equalizer for each channel.
It accepts the following parameters:
name: anequalizer

parameters.name: params
description: This option string is in format: "c
chn f=cf w=w g=g t=f | ..." Each equalizer band is separated by ’|’.
chn
Set channel number to which equalization will be applied. If input doesn’t have that channel the entry is ignored.
f
Set central frequency for band. If input doesn’t have that frequency the entry is ignored.
w
Set band width in hertz.
g
Set band gain in dB.
t
Set filter type for band, optional, can be:
Butterworth, this is default.
Chebyshev type 1.
Chebyshev type 2.

parameters.name: curves
description: With this option activated frequency response of anequalizer is displayed in video stream.

parameters.name: size
description: Set video stream size. Only useful if curves option is activated.

parameters.name: mgain
description: Set max gain that will be displayed. Only useful if curves option is activated. Setting this to a reasonable value makes it possible to display gain which is derived from neighbour bands which are too close to each other and thus produce higher gain when both are activated.

parameters.name: fscale
description: Set frequency scale used to draw frequency response in video output. Can be linear or logarithmic. Default is logarithmic.

parameters.name: colors
description: Set color for each channel curve which is going to be displayed in video stream. This is list of color names separated by space or by ’|’. Unrecognised or missing colors will be replaced by white color.
Reduce broadband noise in audio samples using Non-Local Means algorithm.
Each sample is adjusted by looking for other samples with similar contexts. This context similarity is defined by comparing their surrounding patches of size
p. Patches are searched in an area of r around the sample.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: anlmdn

parameters.name: s
description: Set denoising strength. Allowed range is from 0.00001 to 10. Default value is 0.00001.

parameters.name: p
description: Set patch radius duration. Allowed range is from 1 to 100 milliseconds. Default value is 2 milliseconds.

parameters.name: r
description: Set research radius duration. Allowed range is from 2 to 300 milliseconds. Default value is 6 milliseconds.

parameters.name: o
description: Set the output mode.
It accepts the following values:
i
Pass input unchanged.
o
Pass noise filtered out.
n
Pass only noise.
Default value is o.

parameters.name: m
description: Set smooth factor. Default value is 11. Allowed range is from 1 to 15.
Apply Normalized Least-Mean-Squares algorithm to the first audio stream using the second audio stream.

This adaptive filter is used to mimic a desired filter by finding the filter coefficients that relate to producing the least mean square of the error signal (difference between the desired, 2nd input audio stream and the actual signal, the 1st input audio stream).
A description of the accepted options follows.
name: anlms

parameters.name: order
description: Set filter order.

parameters.name: mu
description: Set filter mu.

parameters.name: eps
description: Set the filter eps.

parameters.name: leakage
description: Set the filter leakage.

parameters.name: out_mode
description: It accepts the following values:
i
Pass the 1st input.
d
Pass the 2nd input.
o
Pass filtered samples.
n
Pass difference between desired and filtered samples.
Default value is o.
Pass the audio source unchanged to the output.
name: anull

description: Pad the end of an audio stream with silence.
This can be used together with ffmpeg -shortest to extend audio streams to the same length as the video stream.
A description of the accepted options follows.
name: apad

parameters.name: packet_size
description: Set silence packet size. Default value is 4096.

parameters.name: pad_len
description: Set the number of samples of silence to add to the end. After the value is reached, the stream is terminated. This option is mutually exclusive with whole_len.

parameters.name: whole_len
description: Set the minimum total number of samples in the output audio stream. If the value is longer than the input audio length, silence is added to the end, until the value is reached. This option is mutually exclusive with pad_len.

parameters.name: pad_dur
description: Specify the duration of samples of silence to add. See
(ffmpeg-utils)the Time duration section in the ffmpeg-utils(1) manual for the accepted syntax. Used only if set to non-zero value.

parameters.name: whole_dur
description: Specify the minimum total duration in the output audio stream. See

(ffmpeg-utils)the Time duration section in the ffmpeg-utils(1) manual for the accepted syntax. Used only if set to non-zero value. If the value is longer than the input audio length, silence is added to the end, until the value is reached. This option is mutually exclusive with pad_dur
Add a phasing effect to the input audio.
A phaser filter creates series of peaks and troughs in the frequency spectrum. The position of the peaks and troughs are modulated so that they vary over time, creating a sweeping effect.
A description of the accepted parameters follows.
name: aphaser

parameters.name: in_gain
description: Set input gain. Default is 0.4.

parameters.name: out_gain
description: Set output gain. Default is 0.74

parameters.name: delay
description: Set delay in milliseconds. Default is 3.0.

parameters.name: decay
description: Set decay. Default is 0.4.

parameters.name: speed
description: Set modulation speed in Hz. Default is 0.5.

parameters.name: type
description: Set modulation type. Default is triangular.
It accepts the following values:
‘triangular, t’
‘sinusoidal, s’

Audio pulsator is something between an autopanner and a tremolo. But it can produce funny stereo effects as well. Pulsator changes the volume of the left and right channel based on a LFO (low frequency oscillator) with different waveforms and shifted phases. This filter have the ability to define an offset between left and right channel. An offset of 0 means that both LFO shapes match each other. The left and right channel are altered equally - a conventional tremolo. An offset of 50% means that the shape of the right channel is exactly shifted in phase (or moved backwards about half of the frequency) - pulsator acts as an autopanner. At 1 both curves match again. Every setting in between moves the phase shift gapless between all stages and produces some "bypassing" sounds with sine and triangle waveforms. The more you set the offset near 1 (starting from the 0.5) the faster the signal passes from the left to the right speaker.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: apulsator

parameters.name: level_in
description: Set input gain. By default it is 1. Range is [0.015625 - 64].

parameters.name: level_out
description: Set output gain. By default it is 1. Range is [0.015625 - 64].

parameters.name: mode
description: Set waveform shape the LFO will use. Can be one of: sine, triangle, square, sawup or sawdown. Default is sine.

parameters.name: amount
description: Set modulation. Define how much of original signal is affected by the LFO.

parameters.name: offset_l
description: Set left channel offset. Default is 0. Allowed range is [0 - 1].

parameters.name: offset_r
description: Set right channel offset. Default is 0.5. Allowed range is [0 - 1].

parameters.name: width
description: Set pulse width. Default is 1. Allowed range is [0 - 2].

parameters.name: timing
description: Set possible timing mode. Can be one of: bpm, ms or hz. Default is hz.

parameters.name: bpm
description: Set bpm. Default is 120. Allowed range is [30 - 300]. Only used if timing is set to bpm.

parameters.name: ms
description: Set ms. Default is 500. Allowed range is [10 - 2000]. Only used if timing is set to ms.

parameters.name: hz
description: Set frequency in Hz. Default is 2. Allowed range is [0.01 - 100]. Only used if timing is set to hz.
Resample the input audio to the specified parameters, using the libswresample library. If none are specified then the filter will automatically convert between its input and output.

This filter is also able to stretch/squeeze the audio data to make it match the timestamps or to inject silence / cut out audio to make it match the timestamps, do a combination of both or do neither.
The filter accepts the syntax [
sample_rate:]resampler_options, where sample_rate expresses a sample rate and resampler_options is a list of
key=value pairs, separated by ":". See the
(ffmpeg-resampler)"Resampler Options" section in the
ffmpeg-resampler(1) manual for the complete list of supported options.
name: aresample

description: Reverse an audio clip.
Warning: This filter requires memory to buffer the entire clip, so trimming is suggested.
name: areverse

description: Reduce noise from speech using Recurrent Neural Networks.
This filter accepts the following options:
name: arnndn

parameters.name: model
description: Set train model file to load. This option is always required.
Set the number of samples per each output audio frame.
The last output packet may contain a different number of samples, as the filter will flush all the remaining samples when the input audio signals its end.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: asetnsamples

parameters.name: nb_out_samples
description: Set the number of frames per each output audio frame. The number is intended as the number of samples per each channel. Default value is 1024.

parameters.name: pad
description: If set to 1, the filter will pad the last audio frame with zeroes, so that the last frame will contain the same number of samples as the previous ones. Default value is 1.
Set the sample rate without altering the PCM data. This will result in a change of speed and pitch.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: asetrate

parameters.name: sample_rate
description: Set the output sample rate. Default is 44100 Hz.
Show a line containing various information for each input audio frame. The input audio is not modified.
The shown line contains a sequence of key/value pairs of the form
key:value.
The following values are shown in the output:
name: ashowinfo

parameters.name: n
description: The (sequential) number of the input frame, starting from 0.

parameters.name: pts
description: The presentation timestamp of the input frame, in time base units; the time base depends on the filter input pad, and is usually 1/sample_rate.

parameters.name: pts_time
description: The presentation timestamp of the input frame in seconds.

parameters.name: pos
description: position of the frame in the input stream, -1 if this information in unavailable and/or meaningless (for example in case of synthetic audio)

parameters.name: fmt
description: The sample format.

parameters.name: chlayout
description: The channel layout.

parameters.name: rate
description: The sample rate for the audio frame.

parameters.name: nb_samples
description: The number of samples (per channel) in the frame.

parameters.name: checksum
description: The Adler-32 checksum (printed in hexadecimal) of the audio data. For planar audio, the data is treated as if all the planes were concatenated.

parameters.name: plane_checksums
description: A list of Adler-32 checksums for each data plane.
Apply audio soft clipping.
Soft clipping is a type of distortion effect where the amplitude of a signal is saturated along a smooth curve, rather than the abrupt shape of hard-clipping.
This filter accepts the following options:

parameters.name: type

It accepts the following values:

atan
cubic
exp
alg
quintic
sin

parameters.name: param

Automatic Speech Recognition
This filter uses PocketSphinx for speech recognition. To enable compilation of this filter, you need to configure FFmpeg with
--enable-pocketsphinx.
It accepts the following options:

parameters.name: rate
description: Set sampling rate of input audio. Defaults is 16000. This need to match speech models, otherwise one will get poor results.

parameters.name: hmm
description: Set dictionary containing acoustic model files.

parameters.name: dict
description: Set pronunciation dictionary.

parameters.name: lm

parameters.name: lmctl

Display time domain statistical information about the audio channels. Statistics are calculated and displayed for each audio channel and, where applicable, an overall figure is also given.
It accepts the following option:
name: astats

parameters.name: length
description: Short window length in seconds, used for peak and trough RMS measurement. Default is 0.05 (50 milliseconds). Allowed range is [0.01 - 10].

parameters.name: metadata
description: Set metadata injection. All the metadata keys are prefixed with lavfi.astats.X, where X is channel number starting from 1 or string Overall. Default is disabled.

Available keys for each channel are: DC_offset Min_level Max_level Min_difference Max_difference Mean_difference RMS_difference Peak_level RMS_peak RMS_trough Crest_factor Flat_factor Peak_count Bit_depth Dynamic_range Zero_crossings Zero_crossings_rate Number_of_NaNs Number_of_Infs Number_of_denormals

and for Overall: DC_offset Min_level Max_level Min_difference Max_difference Mean_difference RMS_difference Peak_level RMS_level RMS_peak RMS_trough Flat_factor Peak_count Bit_depth Number_of_samples Number_of_NaNs Number_of_Infs Number_of_denormals
For example full key look like this lavfi.astats.1.DC_offset or this lavfi.astats.Overall.Peak_count.
For description what each key means read below.

parameters.name: reset
description: Set number of frame after which stats are going to be recalculated. Default is disabled.

parameters.name: measure_perchannel
description: Select the entries which need to be measured per channel. The metadata keys can be used as flags, default is all which measures everything.
none disables all per channel measurement.

parameters.name: measure_overall
description: Select the entries which need to be measured overall. The metadata keys can be used as flags, default is all which measures everything.
none disables all overall measurement.
Adjust audio tempo.
The filter accepts exactly one parameter, the audio tempo. If not specified then the filter will assume nominal 1.0 tempo. Tempo must be in the [0.5, 100.0] range.

Note that tempo greater than 2 will skip some samples rather than blend them in. If for any reason this is a concern it is always possible to daisy-chain several instances of atempo to achieve the desired product tempo.
name: atempo

description: Trim the input so that the output contains one continuous subpart of the input.
It accepts the following parameters:
name: atrim

parameters.name: start
description: Timestamp (in seconds) of the start of the section to keep. I.e. the audio sample with the timestamp start will be the first sample in the output.

parameters.name: end
description: Specify time of the first audio sample that will be dropped, i.e. the audio sample immediately preceding the one with the timestamp end will be the last sample in the output.

parameters.name: start_pts
description: Same as start, except this option sets the start timestamp in samples instead of seconds.

parameters.name: end_pts
description: Same as end, except this option sets the end timestamp in samples instead of seconds.

parameters.name: duration
description: The maximum duration of the output in seconds.

parameters.name: start_sample
description: The number of the first sample that should be output.

parameters.name: end_sample
description: The number of the first sample that should be dropped.
Calculate normalized cross-correlation between two input audio streams.

Resulted samples are always between -1 and 1 inclusive. If result is 1 it means two input samples are highly correlated in that selected segment. Result 0 means they are not correlated at all. If result is -1 it means two input samples are out of phase, which means they cancel each other.
The filter accepts the following options:
name: axcorrelate

parameters.name: size
description: Set size of segment over which cross-correlation is calculated. Default is 256. Allowed range is from 2 to 131072.

parameters.name: algo
description: Set algorithm for cross-correlation. Can be slow or fast. Default is slow. Fast algorithm assumes mean values over any given segment are always zero and thus need much less calculations to make. This is generally not true, but is valid for typical audio streams.

Remap input channels to new locations.
It accepts the following parameters:

parameters.name: map
description: Map channels from input to output. The argument is a ’|’-separated list of mappings, each in the in_channel-out_channel or
in_channel form. in_channel can be either the name of the input channel (e.g. FL for front left) or its index in the input channel layout.

out_channel is the name of the output channel or its index in the output channel layout. If out_channel is not given then it is implicitly an index, starting with zero and increasing by one for each mapping.

parameters.name: channel_layout
description: The channel layout of the output stream.
Split each channel from an input audio stream into a separate output stream.
It accepts the following parameters:
